>You are free to uninstall Jtest and take a chance on shipping untested, sub-optimal code and you are free to keep Jtest installed and have some of the squeakiest clean code on the planet. I know which I'm gonna do.

There is of course at least a third option: uninstall JTest and ship tested, optimal code nevertheless... ;-)

> I would actually interpret these exceptions as an indication of some extra guard conditions and more defensive programming needed within the tested code. If a piece of called code cannot handle unexpected inputs, then the fault lies with the code and not the inputs. :-)

I disagree. If the input violates a precondition, the fault lies with the input, by definition.

Regards, Ilja
